summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against a New York City attorney who was barred by conflicts of interest from representing his wife in a pending divorce action.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Manhattan, on November 21, 2014, the defendant-wife consulted with multiple law firms and then briefly retained a third attorney when she was contemplating suing her husband for divorce. The complaint alleges that the attorney at issue, who was then an associate at Cohen Clair, did not retain her as a client and instead retained another attorney to represent her husband in the litigation. The SEC alleges that, contrary to the representations and practices of the law firms, Cohen Clair retained the attorney she consulted with and failed to identify the other attorney present at the time of the consultation. The court found that Cohen Clair violated the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint, the court also ordered Cohen Clair to pay a civil penalty of $100,000. The settlement is subject to court approval.  The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by Michael J. Kassis and supervised by Jennifer C. Barry of the New York Regional Office. The litigation will be led by Jennifer A. Kasper. The case is being supervised by Joseph G. Sansone, Chief of the Office of the United States District Judge in Manhattan. The Court will determine the amount of disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties to be determined by the court upon motion by the SEC.  In a parallel action, the U.N.
